newsitem.title: USA: Novel Suzuki model so far fails to win audience.
newsitem.headline: Novel Suzuki model so far fails to win audience.

text.p: It was supposed to be Suzuki Motor Corp.'s answer to those adventuresome '90s hipsters who pursue so-called extreme sports, like skyboarding and women's boxing.
But the only thing extreme about Suzuki's X-90 is its dismal sales record.

In the first eight months of 1996, Suzuki sold 2,825 of the X-90 -- a stubby, T-top hybrid between a two-seat sports car and sport/utility vehicle. Company officials predicted they would sell 1,000 a month when the vehicle was introduced a year ago.
Adding further insult are sales promotions usually reserved for day-old doughnuts: buy one, get one free.
At Bob Saks Oldsmobile in Farmington Hills, Mich., a person can buy a 1996 Cutlass Supreme for $19,900 and receive an X-90 on a free one-year lease.

Suzuki has long been a small player in the domestic vehicle market, reaching a sales peak in 1987 with 83,334 units. In 1988, the company was battered by news and consumer group reports that its Samuri minisport-utility was prone to tip over. The company denied the charges, but sales never recovered, falling to 32,751 in 1995.

Last year Suzuki introduced the X-90 and two other new vehicles. They were designed to help the Japanese automaker forge a new image in the minds of American buyers, who mostly associate the company with the rollover controversy.
One year later, the X-90 is far below even its modest sales targets.
"The X-90 has probably been their most disappointing product next to the Samuri," said Steve Kosowski, product and market analyst for AutoPacific Inc., a consulting firm in Santa Ana, Calif.
What went wrong?
Analysts say the concept was flawed. The vehicle is a two-door model with virtually no trunk space and minimal interior storage -- not good for buyers with supposedly active lifestyles.
"It's kind of the answer to the question that nobody asked," Kosowski said.
Positioned as a four-wheel drive, go-anywhere runabout, the X-90 has also been criticised for limited power, excessive road noise and mediocre handling.
Also unfortunate is the fact that competition is stiffer in the mini sport/utility segment.
The RAV4 from Toyota Motor Corp. has proven to be a hit with price-conscious buyers looking for a practical car-based vehicle. Later this year Honda Motor Co. Ltd. will enter the field with its CR-V.

Suzuki officials are sticking behind their product, however, arguing that it will take time for the X-90 to create sufficient awareness and generate a following. Promotions like the one at dealer Bob Saks are aimed at doing just that, said Anne Bryan, a spokeswoman for American Suzuki.
"The X-90 is a very unique car and people either love it or hate it," she said. "It just needs a chance to catch on."

Bryan declined to outline Suzuki's 1997 model year advertising plans. But she said the automaker is considering boosting the profile of the X-90. Meantime, Suzuki is not planning any special incentives or pricing changes.
For their part, Suzuki dealers are bravely touting the vehicle as a niche product that needs to find its niche.
"It's just for a certain populace of the country," said Ken Chancey, sales manager at Kirill Suzuki in Jacksonville, Fla. "We sell all the ones we get."
But Chancey thinks Suzuki should bring the price down. Because the X-90 only has two seats, it has trouble competing with the Suzuki Sidekick, which comes in a four-door version.

For 1997, a four-wheel drive X-90 with manual transmission starts at $15,019, after delivery charges. But an automatic transmission, air conditioning and other options can push the price past the $17,000 mark.
